hypothesis.attack_target: Bulk workspace messages and files from a target Slack workspace exfiltrated to attacker-controlled destinations via a malicious or compromised Slack app.
hypothesis.preconditions: The attacker can operate as a Slack app developer (with a Slack developer account), register and host an app, and reach at least one user or admin in the target workspace via normal communication channels (e.g., email, web). The target workspace allows installation of at least some third-party or custom apps (either directly by users or via admin approval).

attack_flow_hypothesis.step_name: Gain initial app foothold in target workspace
attack_flow_hypothesis.step_description: Attacker publishes or shares a benign-looking Slack app via the Slack App Marketplace or a direct “Add to Slack” URL, then uses consent phishing and the trusted marketplace interface to convince a user or admin in the target workspace to authorize the app with broad read scopes (messages and files).
attack_flow_hypothesis.step_mitre_technique: T1566 / T1199 – Phishing (Consent Phishing) and Trusted Relationship via a malicious Slack OAuth app

attack_flow_hypothesis.step_name: Enumerate users, channels, and file surfaces via Slack APIs
attack_flow_hypothesis.step_description: Using the app’s OAuth tokens, the attacker enumerates users, channels/DMs the app can see, memberships, and file metadata via Slack Web API and Events API, building an internal graph of accounts, permission groups, and high-value locations.
attack_flow_hypothesis.step_mitre_technique: T1087 / T1069 – Account Discovery and Permission Groups Discovery over SaaS APIs

attack_flow_hypothesis.step_name: Automated harvesting of messages and files
attack_flow_hypothesis.step_description: The attacker’s backend systematically pulls message history and file content from prioritized channels and users via the Web API, and subscribes to Events API streams to ingest new high-value messages and files in near-real time.
attack_flow_hypothesis.step_mitre_technique: T1119 / SaaS Messaging Applications – Automated Collection from Slack messages and files

attack_flow_hypothesis.step_name: Exfiltrate harvested content to attacker-controlled destinations
attack_flow_hypothesis.step_description: The backend stages harvested Slack data into bundles and exfiltrates it by posting archives into an attacker-controlled Slack workspace via Web API, and/or uploading them to attacker-owned cloud storage (e.g., via standard HTTPS APIs or storage integrations).
attack_flow_hypothesis.step_mitre_technique: T1567.002 / T1537 – Exfiltration Over Web Service and Transfer Data to Cloud Account

selected_techniques.name: Phishing
selected_techniques.rationale: The attacker’s Slack app cannot access any workspace until a user or admin initiates the install and accepts the OAuth consent dialog. The most realistic way to drive that action is to send targeted messages (email or web-based outreach) containing links to the app’s Slack App Marketplace listing or direct OAuth install URL on slack.com. This matches MITRE Phishing, including “consent phishing,” where a user is tricked into granting permissions to a malicious OAuth application.

selected_techniques.name: Trusted Relationship
selected_techniques.rationale: Slack’s App Marketplace and third‑party integration model create an implicit trust relationship between workspaces and apps that appear in the official directory or are presented as standard Slack integrations. The attacker abuses this relationship by positioning their malicious app as a legitimate productivity or integration tool. Users and admins are more likely to approve it because it is distributed via Slack’s marketplace and install flows, mirroring how threat actors abuse MSPs or cloud partners to reach downstream victims.

method_steps.description: Prepare a benign-looking marketplace presence or install landing flow for the malicious app, ensuring that its listing or install button initiates an OAuth flow requesting broad read scopes (e.g., messages and files) while advertising plausible business value (e.g., analytics, backups, summaries).

The attacker controls backend infrastructure capable of handling Slack OAuth redirects, exchanging authorization codes for tokens, and securely storing app credentials for later use.
constraints_encountered: Workspace and organisation app-governance settings may completely block new apps, restrict installs to a preapproved list, or require admin approval for all apps, reducing the success rate of the phishing and trusted-relationship approach.

During the Slack OAuth consent flow, the full set of requested scopes is displayed to the user/admin; overly broad or obviously unnecessary scopes may raise suspicion and cause them to cancel the install.

Admins can see installed apps and pending app requests in the admin controls; a security-conscious admin may review app descriptions, scopes, and publishers and deny or later remove the malicious app.

If the attacker under-requests scopes during app registration to appear less suspicious, they may not receive sufficient access for the later Collection/Exfiltration objectives, forcing a risky reauthorization request.
Slack or the organization may monitor for new app installs and unusual app permissions, which could flag the malicious app shortly after installation, limiting its dwell time.
evasion_considerations: Design the app’s branding, description, and category in the Slack App Marketplace to match a useful but innocuous productivity or analytics use case, so that broad read scopes appear justified under the trusted Slack integration model.

Request only the minimal set of Slack scopes necessary to read channels and files while aligning them with the advertised functionality, reducing the likelihood that admins perceive the app as over-privileged during the OAuth consent step.

Leverage links to official slack.com marketplace or OAuth URLs in phishing lures so that recipients see a trusted Slack domain rather than an unfamiliar site, increasing click-through and consent rates.

Target specific roles likely to have app-install permissions (workspace owners, admins, or technical champions) instead of mass-mailing, to mimic legitimate vendor outreach and avoid organizational spam filters and scrutiny.

Stagger outreach and installs across time and organizations to avoid creating obvious spikes in new app installs that might trigger automated monitoring or manual review by Slack admins or security teams.
adversarial_methods.comments_for_orchestrator: This method yields valid Slack OAuth tokens with the broad read scopes the attacker registered, providing an Initial Access foothold at the workspace level via a malicious app. Subsequent tactics (Collection and Exfiltration) should assume the attacker has one or more app/bot tokens plus workspace and installing-user identifiers, and can invoke Slack Web API methods consistent with the granted scopes to harvest messages/files and move them off-platform. If you chain this with additional steps, consider branching on whether the workspace allowed direct user install or required admin approval, as that affects how visible/suspicious the app may be to defenders.

selected_techniques.name: Account Discovery
selected_techniques.rationale: With a compromised/malicious Slack app token, the attacker can use the Web API and Events API to enumerate users and bot accounts in the workspace, including roles and basic profile details. This directly aligns with Account Discovery, where adversaries leverage authenticated APIs to list identities and understand who exists in the environment and which accounts may be privileged.

selected_techniques.name: Permission Groups Discovery
selected_techniques.rationale: Slack channels, DMs, and user groups function as permission boundaries that define which users can see which messages and files. Using the Web API, the malicious app can enumerate channels and (where scopes permit) their membership, effectively discovering group-based permission structures and where sensitive data is likely to reside.

preconditions_required: The malicious app already possesses harvested messages and files from the victim workspace on its backend (given in scenario).

The app holds valid OAuth tokens for the attacker-controlled workspace with scopes that allow creating channels/DMs and posting messages and files (e.g., chat:write, files:write, channels:manage/conversations:write as applicable).
The attacker-controlled workspace allows installation of the malicious app with the necessary posting scopes and, if used, allows installation of marketplace integrations like Box or Dropbox Dash.
The backend has network egress and can perform outbound HTTPS requests to public cloud storage providers (e.g., S3, Mega, Google Drive) without being blocked.
The attacker has valid credentials or API keys for the target cloud storage accounts to which the data will be uploaded.
Optional: The attacker has configured any marketplace storage integrations in their workspace to sync a chosen exfiltration channel to attacker-owned external accounts.
constraints_encountered: Slack Web API rate limits on methods like chat.postMessage and file upload operations require the attacker to throttle requests or batch data into fewer, larger archives to avoid 429 responses and delays.

Slack-enforced maximum message length and file-size limits may prevent uploading excessively large raw dumps in a single call, pushing the attacker toward compression, chunking, and multi-part archives.

The malicious app must have obtained sufficient write scopes in the attacker workspace; if installation was mistakenly scoped too narrowly, it may be unable to create channels or upload files to all desired locations.

If marketplace integrations (e.g., Box, Dropbox Dash) are used to propagate content out of Slack, those integrations introduce their own quotas, logging, and access controls that may restrict throughput or increase detection risk.

Cloud storage providers typically log API requests and may enforce rate limits or anomaly detection on large data ingress, influencing how quickly and how much data can be exfiltrated in a single burst.

Use of workflows or custom steps for scheduled exfil requires that workflow creation and execution are permitted in the attacker workspace and that the malicious app is allowed to provide or participate in those steps.
evasion_considerations: Perform exfiltration in a low-and-slow manner, spreading Web API posts and cloud uploads over time to avoid conspicuous spikes in outbound Slack or cloud storage activity.
Compress and encrypt harvested data before uploading it to cloud storage so that provider-side content inspection or casual review of objects does not easily reveal Slack-originating content.
Name exfiltration channels and uploaded archives to resemble benign operational logs or backups (e.g., '#ops-logs', 'backup-2025-01-01.zip') to blend in with typical integration and backup patterns.
If marketplace integrations are used, target channels that already host automated notifications so that additional files and messages appear consistent with existing app traffic.

Batch and summarise messages when posting into the attacker workspace, so that fewer API calls are needed and Slack-level telemetry shows modest, integration-like behaviour rather than raw bulk dumps.
Align scheduled exfiltration workflows with common business hours and expected workflow execution patterns to reduce the chances that periodic uploads appear anomalous in timing-based monitoring.
adversarial_methods.comments_for_orchestrator: This method assumes the collection phase is complete and focuses purely on moving already-harvested Slack data from the malicious app backend to attacker-controlled destinations using documented Slack and web APIs. The primary exfil path is via Slack Web API into an attacker workspace (Exfiltration Over Web Service), with a secondary, higher-volume path via direct HTTPS uploads to attacker cloud storage (Transfer Data to Cloud Account). Optional use of marketplace storage integrations and scheduled workflows can be toggled depending on prior steps in the chain and desired stealth. Subsequent tactics could involve Defense Evasion (e.g., cleaning up workflows or app configurations) or Impact, but are outside this step.

attack_chain_summary_steps: 1. Use consent phishing and a trusted Slack App Marketplace listing or direct install URL to persuade a target user/admin to authorize a malicious Slack app with broad read scopes.
2. With the resulting OAuth tokens, enumerate users, channels/DMs, memberships, and file metadata via Slack Web API and Events API to map where sensitive data and privileged users reside.

3. Systematically harvest historical and real-time messages and files from prioritized channels and users using Web API history and file methods plus Events API streams, storing content on the attacker’s backend.

4. Exfiltrate staged Slack data by posting archives into an attacker-controlled Slack workspace using Web API and, optionally, syncing those channels to attacker-owned cloud storage or directly uploading archives via standard HTTPS APIs.

selected_techniques.rationale: The attacker uses Slack’s own web/desktop UI—especially the enterprise search and Slack AI views—as a consolidated dashboard over Slack and connected SaaS repositories. With valid user credentials, they can inspect which sources are indexed, how much content exists per source, and quickly open or preview items. This matches Cloud Service Dashboard, where adversaries use a cloud console GUI (rather than raw APIs) to enumerate resources and information in an operational environment.

selected_techniques.rationale: Enterprise search indexes messages, files, canvases, and connected third-party apps. This mirrors Cloud Service Discovery procedures (such as AADInternals/ROADTools/Pacu enumerating cloud services) but uses Slack’s AI/search layer as the discovery mechanism.

preconditions_required: Slack AI and enterprise search must be fully enabled for the compromised user account, including permissions to invoke AI summarisation in channels, DMs, canvases, and huddles.

Workspace administrators must have configured at least some third-party SaaS integrations as enterprise search sources, and the compromised user must have sufficient access in those external tools for their content to appear in search results.

Relevant historical content (messages, files, canvases, external documents, and huddle summaries) must have been successfully indexed by the AI indexing and enterprise search pipelines so that it is discoverable.

The compromised user must still be a member of typical knowledge-worker channels where sensitive projects and discussions occur and must not have been restricted or quarantined after account compromise.
constraints_encountered: Enterprise search and Slack AI enforce existing access controls based on channel membership and external app permissions, so the attacker can only discover content that the compromised user is already entitled to access.
Private channels, DMs, and external repositories to which the user does not belong will not appear in search or AI summaries, limiting the discovery scope to the user’s effective permissions.

Org/workspace policies may disable or narrow AI summarisation features (for example, restricting AI usage in canvases or huddle summaries), reducing the attacker’s ability to use AI as a reconnaissance accelerator.
Depending on configuration, some external sources may be excluded from enterprise search, preventing cross-repository discovery even if the integrations exist for other users.
AI and search operations are likely logged and potentially monitored; unusually aggressive or wide-ranging queries and summarisation activity could trigger detection by security or compliance teams.
AI features and enterprise search can be subject to rate limits or usage caps, constraining how quickly the attacker can run repeated summaries across many channels and documents.
evasion_considerations: Blend reconnaissance queries with normal-looking work activity in the Slack client, spacing out AI and search usage to avoid standing out in telemetry as anomalous or high-volume search behaviour.

Prefer AI summaries and high-level overviews of long channels and documents instead of opening or downloading large numbers of individual files, which may reduce the volume of discrete access events and file downloads.
Use natural, business-themed queries (for example, framed around projects or teams) rather than obviously sensitive or highly technical search terms that might be scrutinised by monitoring rules.
Perform discovery during local business hours from typical client platforms (desktop/web) to resemble normal user behaviour patterns and avoid triggering geo- or time-based anomaly detection.
Reuse prior AI responses and search results to refine subsequent queries, minimising the number of new, unusual queries while still expanding the map of systems and repositories.
adversarial_methods.comments_for_orchestrator: Discovery is clearly achievable using only in-product Slack AI and enterprise search. The net result of this method is a detailed mental (or offline) map of: (a) which internal systems and SaaS platforms exist, (b) where sensitive artefacts are stored (channels, canvases, external spaces/folders), and (c) which documents capture architecture, data flows, or incident history. Subsequent tactics such as Collection and Exfiltration can reuse the identified channels, canvases, documents, and external repositories as precise targets, without needing additional privilege escalation in Slack itself. The main limiting factor is the compromised user’s existing access footprint and any organisational policy that restricts AI or enterprise search visibility.

preconditions_required: Slack AI and enterprise search must remain enabled for the compromised user account, with indexing configured for the relevant Slack content (messages, files, canvases, huddles) and any connected third-party applications.
The compromised user must retain membership in the previously identified high-value channels, DMs, canvases, and have permission to open the associated files and connected-app records.
Canvas creation and private sharing rights must be available to the user so that they can create and maintain recon canvases without drawing unnecessary attention.

Workflow Builder must be enabled for standard users in the workspace and allow creation of workflows triggered by message actions/shortcuts that can post into channels or DMs controlled by the attacker.
AI features (including huddle summarisation and canvas assistance) must not be globally disabled on the specific channels or content types the attacker is targeting.
constraints_encountered: Slack AI and enterprise search can only access data the compromised user is permitted to view; private channels or documents outside their access scope will not be reflected in summaries or search results.

Admins may have configured AI or search restrictions per channel, workspace, or data source (including some connected apps), limiting what content is available for aggregation even when the user can see part of it in the UI.

AI summarisation may abstract away or omit specific sensitive strings (such as full passwords or API keys), potentially forcing the attacker to drill back into underlying messages when they need exact values rather than derived knowledge.

Workflow Builder capabilities and available triggers/steps may be constrained by admin policy; some event types, destinations, or external connectors might be unavailable, limiting how automated the collection can be.

Workflow run history and the creation of new workflows, canvases, and private channels can be visible to admins or logged for audit, providing potential forensic evidence of abnormal consolidation activity.
AI and search features may be rate-limited or monitored; issuing very broad or repetitive sensitive-topic queries in a short period could trigger alerts or throttling.
Using message shortcuts to trigger workflows generates visible actions in-channel (e.g., ephemeral messages, reactions, or audit log entries), which could be noticed by attentive users or defenders.
evasion_considerations: Give canvases, workflows, and channels innocuous, business-relevant names (e.g., "Q3 planning notes", "Team triage helper") to avoid drawing attention during casual review or in admin dashboards.

Prefer topic- and project-oriented prompts rather than obviously malicious keywords (e.g., frame AI queries as "summarize discussion about VPN onboarding" rather than "find passwords"), while still extracting useful operational details.

Use Slack AI to aggressively summarise and de-duplicate content so that the final artefacts are compact; this both reduces exfiltration volume and makes the attacker’s activity look like normal knowledge management rather than bulk scraping.

Trigger the "Add to recon log" workflow selectively on the most useful messages instead of every post in a channel, keeping workflow activity low-volume and similar to legitimate lightweight automations.

Perform summarisation and workflow usage during normal working hours, with human-like pacing, so that access patterns blend with typical user behaviour rather than spiking AI/search activity outside usual times.
Store consolidated summaries primarily in private canvases and DMs where access is limited, reducing the chance that other users will stumble upon or question the assembled intelligence.

attack_chain_summary_steps: 1. Sign in as a compromised standard user with Slack AI and enterprise search enabled, and use the Slack client’s AI/search UI to discover which internal and connected-app repositories are indexed.

2. Run broad and then refined AI/search queries to identify specific high-value channels, canvases, files, and external spaces containing sensitive topics (architecture, credentials, incidents, customer data).

3. Create private canvases and a recon-log channel/DM, then use Slack AI, enterprise search, and a lightweight Workflow Builder flow to summarise and centralise the most sensitive findings into a small set of attacker-owned artefacts for later review or exfiltration.

summary:
The Slack Collaboration Platform presents high-value attack paths both through its app platform and through its native AI and search features.

In the first path, a malicious or compromised Slack app uses trusted marketplace distribution and OAuth consent phishing to gain Initial Access. Once installed, the app legitimately calls Slack Web API and Events API to discover users, permission groups (channels/DMs), and file surfaces, then automatically harvests message histories and file contents from prioritized channels. Finally, it exfiltrates data by posting archives into an attacker-controlled Slack workspace and/or uploading them to attacker cloud storage, potentially chaining marketplace storage integrations and workflows for persistence and scale.

In the second path, a compromised but non-admin user exploits Slack AI and enterprise search as a reconnaissance and collection tool. With only end-user capabilities, the attacker can map internal and third-party repositories indexed by enterprise search, identify sensitive channels and documents, and then use AI summaries, canvases, and simple workflows to consolidate knowledge into compact recon artefacts. These canvases and logs are easy to exfiltrate or reuse in later campaigns.

Defensively, Slack admins should strictly govern app installation and scopes, monitor Web API and Events API usage from apps, tightly control Workflow Builder and custom steps, and carefully scope enterprise search sources and Slack AI entitlements. Regular review of installed apps, workflows, AI usage, and search configuration—combined with anomaly detection on high-volume enumeration, collection, or exfiltration patterns—significantly reduces the risk of these attack paths succeeding undetected.
